note.p: Manchester, John Rylands University Library, French 66
Roman de la Rose with preliminary tables of contents and chapter headings (ff. 1v-163v)
Gothic, written in two columns of 35 lines, 2 scribes

1 historiated initial ‘M’ (L’Amans Sleeps) and foliate bar border on f. 7r (with a dog chasing a hare and a hybrid creature wearing a mitre and holding a chalice), and 3 single-column miniatures in colors and brown ink: ff. 22r (Amors Explains His Commandments), 87r (Amors and Barons Come to L’Amans Aid), 87v (Amors Prays for the Birth of Jean de Meun), in red, blue and brown ink. Red and blue pen initials throughout.
English (Fazakerley of Liverpool), 19th century; blue morocco with Johns Rylands monogram (JR) stamped in gold on front cover.

Friars Minim convent at Mons, 17th century ("De Conventu Patrum Minimorum Montensium" written in cursive at the top of f. 1r); John Rylands Library, late 19th century (1894 bookplate, inside upper cover); Rylands library merged with Manchester University Library in 1972.
5 Capitle or chapter titles given in red (f. 1v); prose treatise on the nature of love (ff. 2r-4r); li capitle et li title (ff. 4v-6v). Large number of marginal notes in red.
1. Robert Fawtier, “Deux Manuscrits du ‘Roman de la Rose’,” Romania, 53 (1932), pp. 263-73.

2. Cedric E. Pickford, “‘The Roman de la Rose’ and a Treatise Attributed to Richard de Fournival; Two Manuscripts in the Johns Rylands Library,” Bulletin of the John Rylands Library, 34 (1951-52) pp. 344-49.
This description has been compiled using the site's images and various published sources. If you have corrections or additional information, please do contact us.
